history.content: You should probably focus more on what you like to do best than what recruiters want. Coming out of Berkeley, you are already marketable. I would take upper elective classes that i like the most.

children.subject: CS170 sounds good because its a foundational class for CS in general.  The other classes are more specific applications, so it probably depends on what kind of work you want to do.  168, 186 would probably be more versatile than the other classes, but as the student answer says, its more up to what you want to learn.

history.content:
Hey Piazza Family,

I plan on taking CS61C this upcoming fall and I need advice on two other upper division CS courses to take with them. I know that this is dependent on what my interests and career goals are, but I'm still in the process of figuring out what subdivisions of computer science I do and do not enjoy. I plan on taking some combination of the two courses from the following: CS161, CS168, CS170, CS186, CS188. 

I'm a transfer student heading into my fourth year here at Cal where I'll have another semester in Fall 2018 to complete my coursework. Right now I'm leaning towards taking CS170 for interview purposes and CS186. However, I'm open to suggestions on what I should take as I'm currently having this dilemma of taking courses that'll make me more marketable to recruiters from software engineering companies versus taking classes that are offered only once a year and classes that appeal to my current interests (CS168 and CS161).

TLDR: Recruiting season is almost here so should I take classes that'll prep me for interviews (CS170) or more project-based classes to beef up my resume and make me more marketable?

Thanks everyone!
history.subject: First Upper Division Courses and General Advice
